docs.lead_paragraph: All Jerry Poole wants in the coming year is this: that a surgeon's scalpel slice his great girth open, and that his digestive organs be permanently reconfigured so that he can eat no more than will fit into a pouch the size of a small egg. He wants this so badly, Mr. Poole says, that he would crawl through broken glass for it.

headline.main: More People Opting for Surgery to Treat Obesity

docs.abstract: Increasing number of severely overweight Americans are opting for surgery to combat obesity; Jerry Poole, 570-pound Los Angeles resident who is seeking risky operation, known as gastric bypass surgery, to reconfigure intestines, comments; Dr Mal Fobi, prominent obesity physician who runs surgery clinic in area comments; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Jets' long slide into oblivion is taking the latest batch of assistant coaches headlong into unemployment. And like everyone else who follows the Jets, they don't have a clue about which direction the search team for a head coach -- the experienced twosome of the owner Leon Hess and the president Steve Gutman who seem to do this all the time -- is facing.

headline.main: Jets Leave Coaches Twisting In Wind

docs.abstract: Status of New York Jets assistant coaches for 1997 is uncertain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Big Dutch Insurer To Buy Providian Unit In the biggest acquisition of an American life insurer, Aegon of the Netherlands said that it was buying the insurance business of Providian for $2.62 billion in stock. Life insurers have been rapidly consolidating, pressed by high costs and tough competition for consumers' savings from banks and mutual funds. Aegon also said it would assume Providian debt worth $780 million and preferred stock worth $100 million. And Providian's banking subsidiary will be spun off. $(Page D2.$) Tandy to Close Electronics Chain Tandy said that it would close its Incredible Universe stores, which sell everything from computers to refrigerators to cassette tapes but have been losing money. The company will also close 19 of its Computer City stores and take a charge of $170 against earnings. $(D3.$) NCR's Price: Too High, Even Now? In one of the most disastrous corporate takeovers of recent years, AT&T acquired NCR for $7.48 billion in 1991. Today it is spinning off the computer maker for less than half that, based on the price of NCR's shares in ''when-issued'' trading. Still, some analysts think even that is too high a price. Market Place. $(D6.$) Dow Falls 11.54 on Profit-Taking A wave of late profit-taking snapped the market's eight-day advance. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.54 points, to 6,549.37, trimming its gain for the year to 28 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.63 points, closing at 1,287.75. The losers included some big technology stocks. $(D7.$) Treasury prices were little changed in thin trading in the last full session of the year. The 30-year bond yield edged up to 6.54 percent from 6.53 percent on Friday. $(D13.$) Humana to Cut Hundreds of Jobs Humana, the operator of managed health care plans, said it would cut 700 to 900 jobs, or as much as 5 percent of its work force, next year as it reduces costs to stem a decline in earnings. $(D3.$) Banc One to Grow in Oklahoma Banc One said that it had agreed to buy the Liberty Bancorporation of Oklahoma City for $546 million in stock. Banc One operates in 12 states, and this acquisition would give it 29 branches and $2.9 billion in assets in Oklahoma, making it one of the top three banks in the state. $(D3.$) Merger Could Squeeze Con Edison The proposed merger of Brooklyn Union and Long Island Lighting would put new pressure on the New York area's largest electricity supplier, Con Edison, to lower rates and allow its customers to seek different energy options, analysts said. $(B1.$) Executive Quits At HarperCollins After less than a year as president and publisher of the HarperCollins trade publishing group, Jack McKeown has resigned, the company said. Mr. McKeown's responsibilities will be divided between David Steinberger, a management consultant at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, and Anthea Disney, the president and chief executive of HarperCollins Publishers. $(D4.$) Chinese Growth and Inflation Slow China's robust economy expanded at the slowest rate in five years during 1996. The gross domestic product rose 9.7 percent, down from 10.2 percent in 1995. The Government has been holding back growth in an attempt to curb inflation, which fell to a four-year low of 6 percent from 14.8 percent in 1995. $(D6.$) Stake in Hong Kong Investor Sold Executives of Citic Pacific, China's largest investment vehicle in Hong Kong, acquired 15.5 percent of the company from its state-owned parent, Citic Hong Kong, for $1.4 billion. Their goal is to increase its independence and growth prospects. The Chinese Government will still own 26.5 percent. $(D6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress and the nation gearing up for a huge debate on the future of Social Security, labor, Wall Street, corporate America and organizations of the old and the young are quietly marshaling their forces for one of the biggest lobbying battles in decades. There is a broad consensus that the Social Security system needs reform, but little agreement on what should be done, and many of the important organizations in the debate are formulating their strategies. Nevertheless, the battle has been joined in public relations campaigns and in jockeying for position in Congress.

headline.main: For Interest Groups, Battle Lines Form in Debate Over Social Security

docs.abstract: Wall Street, corporate America and organizations of old and young are quietly marshaling forces for major lobbying battle over Social Security amid broad consensus on need for reform and little accord on what should be done; key issue is how to shift Social Security toward private markets; table (M)
docs.snippet: With Congress and the nation gearing up for a huge debate on the future of Social Security, labor, Wall Street, corporate America and organizations of the old and the young are quietly marshaling their forces for one of the biggest lobbying battles...

docs.lead_paragraph: Urban hospitals are pressuring Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the State Legislature to come up with a permanent source of money to care for indigent, uninsured patients before the end of 1997, to avoid another crisis like the one earlier this year when hospitals were forced to treat so-called charity care patients without being reimbursed. After months of wrangling, lawmakers decided in May to keep using money from the unemployment insurance fund to finance charity care through the end of 1997.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a new idea afoot here, being pushed hard by French leaders: France -- land of revolutions, the avant-garde, the upheavals of 1968 -- has become a ''profoundly conservative'' country deeply resistant to change. The theory, espoused by President Jacques Chirac, is supposed to explain why France is in a funk -- unreceptive to reform, unconvinced by its leaders, unclear about its place in a changing world. In this visceral conservatism, if French leaders are to be believed, lies the reason that France, more than any other European country, has found itself disoriented before the prospect of curtailing the welfare state, creating a flexible labor market, adopting the new technologies of cyberspace and embracing a single European currency, all in order to compete in a global economy.

headline.main: Lacking Barricades, France Is in a Funk

docs.abstract: France, more than any other European country, has found itself disoriented before prospect of curtailing welfare state, creating flexible labor market, adopting new technologies of cyberspace and embracing single European currency, all in order to compete in global economy; Pres Jacques Chirac says this is because France is 'profoundly conservative' country deeply resistant to change; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MY prophecy for 1997 is very simple: it will be just like 1897. This is not just a wild guess, but is based on solid sociological research. What gives the game away is the vogue for cigar smoking. Several times recently I have enjoyed the almost-forgotten smell of cigar smoke in public places. Dark aromatic stores have sprung up in places like Port Jefferson and East Hampton, where men sit in leather chairs puffing on stogies like characters out of Mark Twain. The local bookstore has a display of handsome books about cigars, pipes and fine tobbacos, and I am told that the chic cigar smoking crowd are in the habit of taking over whole restaurants in the Hamptons for unisex smoking parties to which I am never invited.

headline.main: Hip! Hip! for the Old New Year

docs.abstract: David Bouchier comment suggests going back to 1897 in 1997, to escape late 20th-century's obsession with health and enjoy old-fashioned pleasures of art and music we can understand, efficient rail service and even education that teaches children to read, write and do simple arithmetic (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Return to normal society is the toughest problem that faces a man or woman recovering from alcohol, drug or other substance abuse. The truly marvelous system of counselors, recovery centers, hospitals and agencies long dedicated to working with those in recovery were managing pretty well until the sudden advent of managed care a few years ago, which determined how much care an individual would get by controlling how much care managed care would pay for. Great recovery establishments like the Smithers Foundation, Seafield, C. K Post, South Oaks Hospitals and others were either forced by managed care to close or were brought to their knees. Recovery progress was set back by more than half a century to the days when A.A. and, later, the legendary Kenny Mann, got modern medicine to treat alcoholism as a disease, rather than a social aberration.
docs.abstract: Robert J King letter warns that managed care imperils 'sober houses,' great recovery establishments that are essential in helping people climb back from addition (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: CONSIDER the scenario. The jetliner is almost ready for takeoff. Last-minute passengers eager to get seated press forward in a clumsy tangle of elbows, suit bags and wailing babies. But you are already strapped in; your luggage is stowed neatly away. A novel is open on your lap like a prayer book. But then the seat next to you, which can be a buffer of solitude, is not empty. There is a stranger in it with a burning desire to chat. Worse, this unfamiliar face wants to blather endlessly about his most intimate particulars. In this instance, the monologue is about an extramarital affair with a business colleague.

headline.main: The Urge To Blurt Plagues Imperfect Strangers

docs.abstract: Article on apparent increase in number of people who feel the need to reveal the troubles of their lives to casual strangers; some psychologists comment; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE little hammock of time swinging between Christmas and New Year's Day provides a pause of sorts. With minimal effort, the time can be used to assure that travel is more enjoyable in 1997. So here come the snafus of 1996, with a checklist of 12 items for better organized travel.

headline.main: A Dozen Routes To a Calmer '97

docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column offers checklist of 12 items for better organized travel in 1997; drawing (M)
